description:
Chaetomium strumarium is a species of ascomycete fungus that belongs to the genus Chaetomium. It is a saprobic fungus, meaning it decomposes organic matter as a part of its life cycle.

Chaetomium strumarium is characterized by the production of flask-shaped perithecia (fruiting bodies) that are dark in color and covered with characteristic spiral appendages or setae. The ascospores (sexual spores) produced within the perithecia are typically brown, ellipsoidal, and possess a single equatorial germ pore.

This fungus is commonly found growing on various cellulosic substrates, such as paper, textiles, and wood, where it plays a role in the decomposition and recycling of organic carbon. It has been reported to have a global distribution, occurring in both temperate and tropical regions.

Chaetomium strumarium is of interest in the field of mycology and biotechnology due to its potential applications in the production of enzymes, bioactive compounds, and bioremediation of cellulose-containing waste materials.
